@SmallerNNsPls @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Ah, I almost forgot! These are all books on the theory of PDEs. If you're looking for books on numerical solution of PDEs, let me know I can provide a few references for those too.

@chenna1985 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech That's right. The discretization of the data does project into the model. For the graph-based methods, we sample random graphs from the data's discretization, in the hope to alleviate the effect of underlying discretization.

@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech In the end, it's all the same.
You have to use "some data" to train the NN model for the PDE operator, and that "data" must be based on some discretisation of the operator. So, whatever the discretion you used for generating the data is projected onto the operator NN model.
@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Impressive!

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech It'd be great if you could share a repository and scripts to make comparisons. Lots of engineering has gone into PyTorch and it's only fair to use good methods and implementations for the conventional solvers, especially if you report relative timings (which I think is important)

@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Worthy mentioning, the figured experiment is trained on the 64√ó64√ó20 dataset and evaluated on 256√ó256√ó80. Usually, people can only generalize to different spatial resolutions, but we can transfer to different time resolutions.

@ZongyiLiCaltech @ColinJMcAuliffe @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech It's a nonlinear preconditioner (which is okay) and it seems hard to guarantee it is nonsingular. And it has to be faster/more accurate than existing preconditioners like multigrid. Perhaps look at geophysical inverse problems (e.g., tomography) or time-periodic ocean spin-up.

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech I agree. There are many many powerful PDE solvers and researchers have invested hundreds of years into them. We didn't mean to beat all the PDE-solvers. By using the data-driven methods we can save some human efforts to craft these solvers and also save some time of PhD labors.

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech The velocity remains the same order of magnitude. 
And sorry I have to admit that I am not an expert on the conventional solvers (wanna be one). The data generation scripts are written by our applied math collaborators. I can share the code if you want to take a looküôÇ

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech With many orders of magnitude coefficient contrast & coherent structures, it's necessary to use more technical MG methods, which have higher setup costs (per coefficient realization, unless they are similar) and tend to rely on sparse matrices (perf limited by memory bandwidth).

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech The beauty of "conventional" PDE solvers is reliable generalization. FWIW, the low-contrast case you've studied (with or without coherent structures) can be solved to discretization error in 5 work units using geometric multigrid (at any scale, including trillions of dofs).

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Is velocity larger when reducing viscosity (in your normalization of forcing)? And could you be more precise about the time splitting method you've used? It's easy to end up first order or with loss of stability near the imaginary axis. Exponential RK is a good high-order choice.

@gautamcgoel @Stanford @Caltech Ohhh good question üòÖ

@AjitRJadhav @chenna1985 @kazizzad @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech Thanks for your suggestion! We will take a look.

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech I see. This is an interesting dataset. To work on it we probably should generate the synthetic data with a similar measure. How networks generalize from one dataset to another is also a very interesting direction. Thanks for the suggestion!

@ColinJMcAuliffe @five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Agree. Indeed we use the conventional method to generate ground truth data. The main advantage compared to conventional methods is speed. Preconditioners would be can an interesting direction to go!

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Right.. the Re=1000 case is milder. For the Re=10000 case, it comes to the turbulence regime. Reducing delta_t to 1e-3 it immediately starts to blow up. So we are about the stability limit.

@chenna1985 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Hi Chenna! thanks for your interest! Here is the code for the graph-based methods. We haven't tried on complex geometry, because we don't have such dataset.. If you have interesting datasets we would love to try them!üôÇ

@GJ_Both @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Well, the Greens function alone won't make a 'good guess'. The framework alternatively composes integration and activation. The power comes from using them together.

@unsorsodicorda @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Probably bothüòÖ

I feel like it's easier to learn a mathematical subject when you have concrete ways of grounding to something physical. So learning both the abstraction and the application in parallel seems more appealing to me.

@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Very interesting! Minor typo in the title of sec. 5.3 Navier-Stoke ‚Üí Navier-Stokes.  I'm especially curious about the turbulence results. What did you compute, isotropic decaying turbulence?  A must read for this weekend!

@harishsbhat @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech The point was, these methods do not require the data to be generated from a solver, it can be from measurements or other ways.

Regarding the classical methods and using "zero data", seems like dangerous topics to make twitter statements on.

@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @ZongyiLiCaltech @Caltech certainly i see what you mean & appreciate the clarification :) data is cheap now, as you say ... when i was a grad student @caltech (2000-05), generating 1000 Navier-Stokes solutions in 3d (for diff values of viscosity etc) would have taken a little longer than in 2020 ;-)

@chenna1985 @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech Again, I would recommend looking at the first two papers. The "methods" in those "papers" are for general/arbitrary meshes. The "papers" do not have Navier Stokes experiments, but the "methods" are independent of the equation, or even PDEs and applicable to your setting...
@AjitRJadhav @kazizzad @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech It is just curve-fitting! Nothing more, nothing less.

@kazizzad @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech thanks for clarifying :) to answer your q: classical numerical methods for pde's don't peek at any examples of the solution (from measurements, simulations, etc) in order to generate solutions ... perhaps from your point of view, such methods use "zero data" ?

@harishsbhat @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech Great q, of course (under some regularity conditions), that is exactly one of the main points in this line of works we have on operator learnings. 
Note that, for such a big problem, if you can afford training, and data gathering, under some assumptions on the spaces, why not.
@kazizzad @harishsbhat @ZongyiLiCaltech @Caltech And the key is we can solve PDE on entirely new parameter settings than training data. So that is solving from scratch..don't you think?

@kazizzad @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech No. But you tried!
My question is about the applicability of your approach for solving Navier Stokes (original post) over complex domains.
@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Wow, congratulations!

@five9a2 @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech It would guess that across a very large class of problems there are probably a lot of cases where a conventional method would be more accurate, but  the NN method seems like it would make for an ideal preconditioner for the conventional method

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech So you're basically using the greens function as a 'good guess' for the operator and then improve on it using your activation function?

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Thank you!
I am interested in problems with complex geometries. But uniform grids are not of much help for such problems.  Given my limited knowledge in NNs, I am happy to use your model based on graph-based methods as a black-box to run some benchmarks. Could you please share?

@GJ_Both @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Good question! The neural operator composes linear integral operators (Greens function) with non-linear operators (activation functions). Just like neural networks can approximate highly non-linear functions, our model can approximate non-linear operators / non-linear PDEs.

@AnimaAnandkumar @KyleCranmer @kazizzad @Caltech Great work to follow! Wouldn't it be great to combine interpretable (geometric) ML with such works at some point to find generalized conditions and equations for existence of smooth solns & turbulence leading to there theoretical understandings [solving the open problem] üôÇ

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech And sorry I am not quite familiar with the SPE10 benchmark. To train the neural operator, we need to have a dataset of inputs and outputs. So if this dataset consists of only one equation, it will be hard to train the operator.

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Good question! Our ground truth data are generated with resolution 256*256 and delta_t=1e-4. 
If we set delta_t=1e-3, it gets ~1.4% error compared to the 1e-4 one; if delta_t=1e-2, it gets ~2.3% error; with 1e-1, it blows up. Our method does as good as the 1e-3 one.
@AnimaAnandkumar @ZongyiLiCaltech @kazizzad @Caltech But you do show that it works really well on non-linear equations, so is your model implicitly linearizing the underlying PDE?

@AnimaAnandkumar @ZongyiLiCaltech @kazizzad @Caltech Cool work and excited to check it out! If I understand it correctly, you're basically learning the Greens function, right? If I remember correctly, the Greens function approach only (officially) works for linear differential equations 1/2

@ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Thanks. How much can the standard spectral solver (with classical time integrator) be coarsened before its accuracy becomes worse than your method?

Also, have you tested the Darcy method with high-contrast coefficients and coherent structures, such as a layer of SPE10 benchmark?

@five9a2 @AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech Hi Jed, in the paper we do [0,10] -> [0, T] just to compare with the existing RNN-based methods. Our method can indeed work on 0 -> [0, T] or 0 -> T. 
For the Re=1000 case, the 3d-Fourier method gets ~0.8% error on [0,10]->[0,T]; ~1.2% error on 0->[0, T]; and ~2% error on 0->T.
@AnimaAnandkumar @kazizzad @Caltech I do solve PDEs for my work but never using  deeplearning methods. What is a good starting point to understand how it is done ? Thank you.

@sidkumar_ @ZongyiLiCaltech @AnimaAnandkumar @Caltech If you may call that beautiful and power approach in RKHS a "trick" ;) Joke aside, it has some flavors of that, but it is more of a Nystr√∂m approximation than spaning RKHS. In this machinery, you can approximate integral operators with sets of point evaluations on your domain :)
